member.name: T:TorSteroids.Common.DateTimeExt
member.summary: Supports DateTime to be able to parse ISO 8601 / RFC2822/RFC822 formatted dates, and more

member.name: M:TorSteroids.Common.DateTimeExt.ParseIso8601DateTime(System.String)
member.summary: Converts an ISO 8601 date to a DateTime object. Helper method needed to deal with timezone offset since they are unsupported by the (older or other targeted) .NET Framework(s).
member.returns: DateTime instance with time converted to Universal Time (UTC)
member.remarks: See also W3C note at: http://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime

member.name: M:TorSteroids.Common.DateTimeExt.ParseRfc2822DateTime(System.String)
member.summary: Parse is able to parse RFC2822/RFC822 formatted dates. DateTime instance with date and time converted to Universal Time (UTC) is returned on success.
member.returns: DateTime instance with time converted to Universal Time (UTC)
member.exception: On format errors parsing the if it match RFC 2822 but another unexpected error occurs, or the could not be parsed

member.name: F:TorSteroids.Common.DateTimeExt.ZoneBias
member.summary: Time zone to bias hours map

member.name: F:TorSteroids.Common.DateTimeExt.ZoneAbbrBias
member.summary: Time zone abbreviations to bias hours map
member.remarks: We do NOT consider non-uique time zone abbreviations, like "ADT", "AMST" or "AMT"... except "CST" / "EDT" - where we use North/Central American Time and Eastern Daylight Time - that are mostly common; see http://www.timeanddate.com/library/abbreviations/timezones/ !!!

member.name: M:System.DateTimeExtensions.DateToInteger(System.DateTime)
member.summary: Returns the date part as integer in the format YYYYMMDD.

member.name: M:System.DateTimeExtensions.TimeToInteger(System.DateTime,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns the time part as an integer in the format HHmmssfff.
member.param: Set this to true, if the provided time is not already a UTC time, else false. If it is true, a conversion to UniversalTime will happen! Default is: false

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.InvokerParameterNameAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the function argument should be string literal and match one of the parameters of the caller function. For example, ReSharper annotates the parameter of .

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.NotifyPropertyChangedInvocatorAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the method is contained in a type that implements interface and this method is used to notify that some property value changed.
member.remarks:
The method should be non-static and conform to one of the supported signatures:
NotifyChanged(string)
NotifyChanged(params string[])
NotifyChanged{T}(Expression{Func{T}})
NotifyChanged{T,U}(Expression{Func{T,U}})
SetProperty{T}(ref T, T, string)

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.CanBeNullAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the value of the marked element could be null sometimes, so the check for null is necessary before its usage.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.NotNullAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the value of the marked element could never be null

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.ContractAnnotationAttribute
member.summary: Describes dependency between method input and output.
member.syntax:
Function Definition Table syntax:
FDT ::= FDTRow [;FDTRow]*
FDTRow ::= Input => Output | Output <= Input
Input ::= ParameterName: Value [, Input]*
Output ::= [ParameterName: Value]* {halt|stop|void|nothing|Value}
Value ::= true | false | null | notnull | canbenull
If method has single input parameter, it's name could be omitted.
Using halt (or void/nothing, which is the same) for method output means that the methos doesn't return normally.
canbenull annotation is only applicable for output parameters.
You can use multiple [ContractAnnotation] for each FDT row, or use single attribute with rows separated by semicolon.

item.code: [ContractAnnotation("halt <= condition: false")] public void Assert(bool condition, string text) // Regular Assertion method
[ContractAnnotation("s:null => true")] public bool IsNullOrEmpty(string s) // String.IsNullOrEmpty
[ContractAnnotation("s:null=>false; =>true,result:notnull; =>false, result:null")] public bool TryParse(string s, out Person result)

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.CannotApplyEqualityOperatorAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the value of the marked type (or its derivatives) cannot be compared using '==' or '!=' operators and Equals() should be used instead. However, using '==' or '!=' for comparison with null is always permitted.

member.summary: Tells code analysis engine if the parameter is completely handled when the invoked method is on stack. member.typeparam: The type to be chained by the fluent context.

member.name: T:TorSteroids.Common.Fluent.IFluentInterface
member.summary: Interface that is used to build fluent interfaces and hides methods declared by from IntelliSense.
member.remarks:
Code that consumes implementations of this interface should expect one of two things:
When referencing the interface from within the same solution (project reference), you will still see the methods this interface is meant to hide.
When referencing the interface through the compiled output assembly (external reference), the standard Object methods will be hidden as intended.
See http://bit.ly/ifluentinterface for more information.
For Resharper users: you just need to configure resharper to respect the attribute. In Resharper Options, go to Environment | IntelliSense | Completion Appearance and check â€œFilter members by [EditorBrowsable] attribute.
